A telegram from an industry source reports that on July 29, a Brazilian plane flew dangerously low over four fishing trawlers off Georgetown, raising concerns about potential accidents due to the vessels‘ extended outriggers. Additionally, the Texas trawler State Line is at risk of sinking off Cape Orange. The report has also reached Congressman Gibbons.

On January 14, 1957, President Castello Branco announced a decision regarding the control of aviation in Brazil. The Navy will manage helicopters for various missions, while the Air Force will control fixed-wing aircraft. A joint training center is to be established. The decision, justified by financial and military considerations, received a generally favorable press reaction, with minimal public dissent from the Air Force or Navy.

Assistant General Mianagar for International Activities,  ES REPORT, AUGUST 14 - 27. 1971  1* 'French Nuclear Tests, France exploded a one-megaton hydrogen  bcunb over Mlururoa Atoils in its most important and most powerful nuclear  test of the year, A French spokesman said the U-235 weapon was the first  true prototype of a thermonuclear warhead in the range intended for strategic  nuclear forces from 1975 on. These will include 58 Mirage bombers, of  which 36 will be airborne around the clock daily starting in. 1976, (Brazil  Herald, 8-15-71, based on UPI dispatch from Papeete,, Tahiti,)  The test was made despite "repeated protests" by the governments of Peru,,  Chile, and Ecuador., After the test, the Peruvian Foreign Miinister reiterated  his protest over the French explosions. The National Agrarian University of  Peru, working in conjunction with the National Junta for Control of Atomic  Energy,, declared that radioactive contamination, from the French tests was  present in the pastures of the Andean region of Peru, "It is certain" -- said the University -- "that there exists a strong correlation between latitude  and the degree of contamination. In the areas situated adjacent to Ecuador,,  which are the most affected (Departments of Lima, Pasco6 Junin, lea,  Arequipa. Puno„ and Tacna), there occurred greater contamination, with  the pastures of Tacna,, which forms the border with Chile, being the most  affected," (Jornal do Brasil,, 8-15-71, based on UPI-Latia-Reuters-AFP- JB reports from Arequipa and Paris)  "GENERAL ALERT: AIRCRAFT MEASURE ATOMIC POLLUTION IN  BRAZIL" was the banner headline in Rio's "O Jornal" of 8-20-71, In inner  page stories, the paper reported fairly factual interviews with PUC's  Father Thomas Cullen (also a USAEC research contractor) and Prof, Rex  Nazare Aives of the CNEN Dosimetry Laboratory, In addition,* it was  reported that two new earthquakes in the north of Peru had reinforced that  government's decision to break diplomatic relations with France if it  exploded any more bombs in the Pacific, The Peruvian V ar Minister disa­ greed with the French attitude that the bomb tests were not dangerous.  The Peruvian member of the Interamerican Juridical Committee,, which was  meeting in Rio0 stated that the French tests had caused higher radioactivity  even in Brazil, tie said that the Bk physics Institute of the Federal U, of RECcIV'~r> ""HO AGR4-1 Atomic Energy Activities Report On September 10, 1971, a report highlighted French nuclear tests, including a one-megaton hydrogen bomb explosion at Mururoa Atoll, amidst protests from Peru, Chile, and Ecuador due to radioactive contamination. The Peruvian Foreign Minister expressed concerns over contamination affecting Andean pastures, particularly in Tacna. Brazilian media reported on aircraft measuring atomic pollution amid rising tensions and potential diplomatic repercussions against France.

Attention has now turned to the staggering amount  of legislation Congress must pass before the December 1 recess.  RequQSts to Try DeputiQS. The Chamber and Justice Committee acted  on October 20 on four requests to try deputies for common crimes. Most  of the cases were old and, in many instances, the statute of limitations  had already run out. Three of the requests were turned down, but at the  insistence of Deputy Guilhermino de Oliveira (PSD-Minas Gerais), permis­ sion was granted to try him in connection with an automobile accident in  Rio de Janeiro.  The press reported that the General Investigating Committee (CGI)  cases against Chamber President Ranieri Mazzilli (PSD-Sao Paulo) and  Deputies Ulisses Guimaraes^(PSD-Sao Paulo) and Cesar Prieto (PTB-Rio Grande  do Sul) were sent to the Sao Paulo State Prosecutor by the CGI. This would  be the first step toward a trial of the deputies for alleged illegal acti­ vities in the Federal Income Tax Agency in Sao Paulo. Rjty^ pjj ^  Legislation and Committees DEC 11 f 2964  President Castello Branco sent the Land Statute, accompanying legis­ lation to his agrarian reform constitutional amendment, to Congress  October 30. Congress will have 30 days in which to decide on the material.  The Land Statute has been changed most importantly in its provisions on  the rural land tax to agree with the new version of the constitutional  J  UNCLASSIFIED  Drafted by' DS-323 FOR PEPT. Argentine Sensitivities Toward Brazil Sharply Increase 12/24/1971 DEPARTMENT OF STATE  Washington. D.C. 20S2O  5 S/S 7120572  RS/R FILES  Attention **  CONFIDENTIAL  0 r MEMORANDUM FOR MR. HENRY A. KISSINGER  COPIEF TO: THE WHITE HOUSE  J  'c,-/pc Subject: Argentine Sensitivities Toward Brazil  n_ Sharply Increase  Argentina is extremely concerned that the United  States may have selected Brazil as its chosen instrument  in dealing with Latin America and that the United States  may be encouraging or permitting Brazil to establish a  form of hegemony over the rest of Latin America. The  long-standing Argentine animosity toward and envy of  Brazil have been sharply exacerbated by the visit of  President Medici of Brazil to Washington and the resultant  press reports suggesting that the U.S. has singled out "5  Brazil as the most important nation in Latin America. A ^  rash of editorials has broken out in the Argentine press  decrying what they assume to be official U.S. Government y  policy to place Brazil at the head of Latin America. The ^  Medici visit has also triggered off a flurry of rumors s\  and speculation about a possible U.S. invitation to  Argentine President Lanusse to visit Washington.  Argentine officials have queried Embassy officers  about press statements emanating from Washington during  the visit of the Brazilian president which suggested that  the U.S. Government considers Brazil to be the most  important country in Latin America. In pursuance of their  apprehensions about Argentina's being discarded, senior  Foreign Ministry officials in Buenos Aires have told  United States officials that they believe Argentina has  an important although modest role to play in the Southern  Cone, exercising a moderating influence over countries  such as Peru, Bolivia, Paraguay, Uruguay, and, to some  extent, Chile.  CONFIDENTIAL MICROFILMED  *«A-U/AT0 -.vif -S.TOIVW.1 BY S/S-I POLITICAL AFFAIRS & RELATIONS The memorandum from the U.S. Department of State expresses Argentina‘s growing concern over the U.S. favoring Brazil in Latin American affairs, particularly after Brazilian President Medici‘s Washington visit. Argentine officials fear being sidelined and have voiced their belief in Argentina‘s significant role in the region. The situation has led to increased tension and negative press in Argentina regarding U.S. policy.

Eclipse Brought Into Focus  POLITICAL  1. Election Developments and Prospects  Federal Deputy Walter Peracchi Barcelos was indirectly chosen as the state's  next governor by the RG-S Legislative Assembly in its session of September 5.  He received 25 votes; 5 blank ballots were cast; the 22 MDB deputies  stayed away. Since his election, he has been vigorously campaigning on  behalf of the ARENA candidates for the state and national legislatures, and  he feels confident that he will secure a small but adequate majority in the  Assembly to enable him to carry out his program of government. He is  reasonably well-liked personally, and some of the bitterness created by the  cassation process which was used to secure his victory seems to have dis­ appeared. The trouble lies in the rivalries and arguments which have plagued  AREHA since it first came into existence in this state, and which are by no  means being shelved for the sake of presenting a united front to the MDB foe. January 18 Statement of FMP (Popular Mobilization Front) L-8& CONFIDENTIAL  Department of State  INFO : POLAD/CINCSO  AMB  mm  ]*OL(5)  POL/R  SVCATT  IHNECCN  ECON  FINATT  LABATT  BraeiliaI I ITB AmEmbassy RIO DE JANEIRO January 22, 1964  January 18 Statement of FMP (Popular Mobilization Front)  Popular Mobilization Front (FMP) leaders met in Leonel  Brizola's Rio apartment on January 18 and issued a statement  which seems to condition FMP support for President Ooulart on,  among other things, "immediate" action in the following fields  which, the document stated, are "ail within the exclusive  competence of the President": a) Institution of exchange and  coffee export monopolies; b) breaking off negotiations on the  AMFORP case, and the expropriation of public service concessions,  «-)including the Hanna concessions; e) expropriation of the  •^Oapuava refinery; f) measures against speculation by "foodstuff  monopolies" and the nationalization of foreign meat packers,  mills, powdered milk plants and pharmaceutical industry;  g) signing of the SUPRA land expropriation decree, which should  not include "small and medium properties"; h) a return to  their original units of sergeants transferred because of  "political persecution"; J) "democratization" of the press,  radio and television.  The statement also a) called for "effective respect for  the policy of self-determination and non-intervention, notably  in relation to Cuba, and support of the struggle of the  Panamanian people in defense of their territorial integrity";  b) reaffirmed the validity of the FMP statements of December  17-16 and "in particular" of Pernambuco Governor Arraes1  statement of December 18 (lunbtel 1270); and c) said that the  FMP will "intensify the mobilisation of the people by all  possible means".  GROUP 3: Downgrade at 12-yr intervals,  not automatically declassified.  CONFIDENTIAL  POL:AArbnales/rstp DCM - Minister Main  DECLASSIFIED  AuthorityjJ lO P S"3 I POL 13 Non-PartyBlocs FMP PopularMobilizationFront 1965 On January 18, 1964, leaders of the Popular Mobilization Front (FMP) met in Rio de Janeiro, issuing a statement outlining conditions for supporting President Goulart. Key demands included monopolies on exchange and coffee, expropriation of concessions, and media democratization. They also called for respect for self-determination policies and pledged to intensify public mobilization.

Revised Bank of Brazil accounts indicate that the net foreign asset  position of the Brazilian monetary authorities improved by only $3«9  million during the first semester of 19^7, not $24.1 million as pre­ viously reported. Following relative stability during the first semester  the net foreign asset position deteriorated sharply during July and August  by slightly more than $100 mi Hi or. and weekly estimates show a further  decline of almost $90 million tnrough October 20 as shown in Table I.  2. The deterioration in net foreign assets during July was anticipated  owing to the low level of coffee receipts and the heavy repayments of  suppliers credits and project loans during that month, but August should  have shewn some improvement. The major cause of the deteriorating  foreign exchange position which continued into October has been heavy  speculation against the cruzeiro. This speculation started early in  August and intensified following the implementation of Central Bank  Resolution 62 control on the manual market which was interpreted as a  sign of a low level of exchange reserves (See A-204, August 31* 1967).  3. The exchange speculation took two major forms: early closing of  exchange contracts for imports and financial remittances through In­ struction 289. As importers closed exchange contracts for imports,  the commercial banks obtained the necessary exchange cover from the  Bank of Brazil (agent for the Central Bank). Exchange cover provided  to the "private banks rose from an average of $7 million per month  earlier in 1967 to $44 million in July, $80 million in August and $124  million in September. Environmental Aspects of AID Program DEPARTMENT OF STATE  )OM OPEV  DDOM AflOM  ADDP ./ARDO 3 MGEX SCIATT FFDO 3  ADMG HRO-3 ITNflT.AgcjTTrTET)  ADPR/ HSO -3 MGSG_3*  ADCD ENRO CDII  DPEC JO - GHRON CLASSIFICATION  DISTRIBUTION For each address checlc one ACTION  AID/WASHINGTON TQAIM 500  OFFICIAL  COI INFO PRM 6  DATE REC'D. *£Ar?\  DATE SENT  5/27/70 FROM - AMEMBASSY, RIO DE JANEIRO  SUBJECT - ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS OF AID PROGRAM  bcfeeie^ TOAID A-688,March 25, 1970 and Embassy A-219 of April 30, 1970  REFERENCE —  We welcome AID's concern with environmental problems in developing countries.  Environmental problems are the concern of a very small element among Brazil's'  technical elite and the editorial writers of several of the country's more re­ sponsible newspapers. Probably as a consequence of local awareness of growing  U.S. concern with environmental problems as well as the growing magnitude of  such problems in Brazil, the beginnings of policy attention have emerged here in  recent years.  Efforts to control water pollution and to re-plant the country's disappearing  forest reserves are receiving particular attention. The Amazon as an area is re­ garded by many literate Brazilians as one of the country's contributions to world  environmental reserves, but foreign interest in this area is received with sus­ picion by most Brazilians. Notwithstanding this interest, the possibilities of  world cooperation in environmental matters appears to make more sense to Brazil­ ian engineers and scientists than to the Brazilian Foreign Office. (During his  recent trip to Brazil, AID's Science Advisor, Dr, Schweitzer, was informed by a  Foreign Office spokesman^ that international cooperation on environmental pro­ blems was a rich country's luxury.)  USAID makes a special effort to minimize unfavorable environmental side effects  on its development projects. For example, pollution control is included in the  engineering design of those capital projects we support directly. The malaria erad­ ication PASA group is well aware of the potential risks of using DDT,and currently  new forms of this insecticide, which hopefully will break-down more rapidly, are  being tried on an experimental basis. There is, of course, in any major development  project an impact on environment, and AID/W guidelines for better judging this  impact would be welcomed. While some Brazilian elites acknowledge these problems, there‘s skepticism towards foreign interest, especially regarding the Amazon. The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) emphasizes minimizing environmental impacts in its projects and seeks better guidelines for assessing these effects.

Hides & Skins: Trade Fair and Convention in Sao Paulo /ACTION  DEPARTMENT OF STATE  FOR RM USE ONLY  A-926 UNCLASSIFIED  INR HANDLING INDICATOR  TO  FROM  SUBJECT :  REF Department of State  BRANCH ^  Amembassy BUENOS AIRES DATE: March 12, 1964  HIDES & SKINS: Trade Fair and Convention in Sao Paulo  r ~i  NSA  3 Sao Paulo, Brazil, will be the seat of a trade exhibition of  Latin American hides from March 14 to 22, and the Third Convention of  the Latin American Association of the Tanning Industry (ALAIC) on  March 17 and 18.  ALAIC is an aasociation of some 1,700 tanning firms in Argentina,  Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, Paraguay, Peru, Ecuador, Columbia, Mexico,  and Venezuela, affiliated with the International Council of Tanners.  The association, which has been in existence about one year, is dedicated  to the promotion of the tanning trade and the exchange of technical  information concerning the industry in Latin America. Association  representatives in Argentina estimate that there are roughly 170 million  head of cattle in ALAIC countries, permitting an annual production  of 28 million hides. ALAIC affiliates produce approximately $US 300  million of tanned hides per year, of which Argentina represents 25$.  The current President of ALAIC is Francisco GRUNWALD of Argentina,  who is also Secretary of the Argentine Chamber of Tanners (Cgmara  Gremial de Curtidores). At the Sao Paulo Convention, the Presidency  will automatically rotate to a Brazilian and the Vice Presidency to  a Colombian for a year term, according to ALAIC1s present statutes.  The convention will inter alia consider Argentine proposals for  making the method of selecting ALAICs authorities an elective process  and establishing an annual budget of at least $US 5,900 with each nation's  share based on the value of its production. Department of State  Info s Brasilia^ Hio de Janeiro, Sao P^^foo^^  AmOonaul, Porto Alegre October 171969  Biographic Notes on :Jcneral of the Army Krailio GarSbtasu  Medici, President ^ilect of Brazil /  lo Family Background; Both the Garastazu and t^-ie Medici  families are substantial and respected in the region of Bage on  the Uruguayan border. Neither is an old family in the tradit­ ional sense, however. On both sides^the families were more or  less established by General Garastazu Medici's grandfathers.  His Medici grandfather emigrated from Italy late in the last  century and attempted to enter Brazil but was unable to do so  because he was not able to establish that he and his wife were  legally married. !Ie was ultimately successful in gaining en­ trance to Uruguay and the family finally settled on the Uru­ guayan border with Brazil. The General s Garastazu grandfather  was a more colorful character. A cattle drover and cowboy, he  drifted iiito the region as a young man late in the last cen­ tury, probably from either Argentina or Uruguay. By the time  of his death at the age of eighty two he had spawned a large  family and acquired considerable holdings in land and cattle.  According to family legend he could ait a horse as well as his  sons and grandsons almost to the tin^ of his death, and even  ride them into the ground, Garastazu is a Basque name, and the  General's grandfather combined the characteristics for which the  race is famous - personal toughness, shrewdness, stubbornessii  and taciturnity. Many of these chareoteriatics are shared by  the General.  2. General ;imillo Garastazu Medici was born in Bage on Dec­ ember k.g 1909';-J50 Emillo Medici and Julia Garastazu Medici,  is one of five children. One of his brothers became a noted  doctor in Porto Alegre. Others ore ranchers or professional  men. hike many families in the region both the Medici and He POL 15-1 Heads of State 1969 (Classified) The document provides biographic notes on General Emilio Garastazu Medici, President of Brazil, detailing his family background. Both the Garastazu and Medici families, emerging from humble origins, gained respect in Bage, near the Uruguayan border. His Italian grandfather struggled with legal marriage to enter Brazil but settled in Uruguay, while the Garastazu grandfather was a cattle drover known for personal toughness. General Medici was born on December 4, 1909.

Cocoa Zone  The drafting officer, Vice Consul Raymond Collins^and BPAO  John Mason attended a conference of mayors at Ilheus from  June 28-30. Organized by the young and energetic Mayor of  Ilheus, Nerival Barros (ARENA), the conference attracted most  of the mayors in the cocoa zone as well as Governor Luis  Viana Filho, State Secretaries of the Interior and Municipal­ ities and representatives of SUDENE, SUDEPE, SESP, BNH, SAAE,  SERFHAU, DERBA etc. The cocoa zone is located on the south­ ern litoral of Bahia and maintains a population in excess of  1,000,000. Though cocoa has long been Bahia's leading ex­ port, the wealth accumulated through its cultivation and in­ dustrialization has not filtered down to the people living  in the area.  The purpose of the conference was to focus attention on the  technical and social needs of the cocoa zone and to formu­ late comprehensive regional planning fully integrated with  state and federal development schemes. At the conclusion  of the conference a loose organization called the ^Alliance  of Mayors in the Reconcavo" was formed. It will be/respon­ sibility of this group to undertake an inventory of the re­ gion's most pressing needs, draw up specific projects in  such fields as health, education, housing, communications  and power and channel these projects to an appropriate state,  federal or international agency for consideration. The “Alliance of Mayors in the Reconcavo“ was established to address issues in health, education, housing, and more, aiming for integrated regional planning.

Seed Industry Development Project OPTIONAL FORM NO. 10  MAY 1062 EDITION  GSA FPMR (41 CFR) 101-11.6  UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT Memorandum  TO : Mr. William A. Ellis, DOM / DATE: July 7, 1970  THRU: Mr. William Gelabert, ADPRK -fn/L  FROM : William L. Rodgers, Chief, ARD0$^  SUBJECT: Seed Industry Development Project  512-15-130-247.3  During a recent PROP review session for the Seed Industry Development  project held in the Program Office it was pointed out that most of the  project targets, as stated in the present PROP, will have been achieved by  the scheduled phase-out date of approximately March 31, 1972. However,  ARDO felt strongly that certain of the project activities will not have  been completely realized to any outstanding degree by scheduled phase out  and therefore should be extended beyond that date. Specifically, I feel  that in the areas of seed research and promotion the project has not as  yet made any significant, lasting contribution. This is due largely to  U.S. personnel and financial limitations. (In 1968 the contract was  reduced from 5 to 2 American technicians).  Accordingly, ARDO has recently submitted budget worksheets  providing a cost breakdown for the extension of contract LA-165 with  Mississippi State University to March 31, 1974. This two-year extension  recommendation is also presently being spelled out in a revised draft of  the PROP for Seed Industry Development to be submitted to AID/W.  It should further be pointed out that the extension of the project  in the areas of seed research and promotion would also have a definite  complementary role to play in the various commodity research projects  which are included in the pending agricultural research loan. I strongly  feel that this new role for Mississippi State University will be  important and basic to our overall agriculture research program.  Your favorable consideration of the above indicated extension is  hereby officially requested.  Buy U.S. Savings Bonds Regularly on the Payroll Savings Plan PRM 1-2 Assistance Plans 5 On July 7, 1970, William L. Rodgers advocated for extending the Seed Industry Development Project beyond its March 31, 1972 phase-out due to insufficient achievement in seed research and promotion. He cited personnel and financial constraints, highlighting the need for continued collaboration with Mississippi State University. An extension until March 31, 1974, is being proposed for additional impact on agricultural research.

Organized by the young and energetic Mayor of  Ilheus, Nerival Barros (ARENA), the conference attracted most  of the mayors in the cocoa zone as well as Governor Luis  Viana Filho, State Secretaries of the Interior and Municipal­ ities and representatives of SUDENE, SUDEPE, SESP, BNH, SAAE,  SERFHAU, DERBA etc. The cocoa zone is located on the south­ ern litoral of Bahia and maintains a population in excess of  1,000,000. Though cocoa has long been Bahia's leading ex­ port, the wealth accumulated through its cultivation and in­ dustrialization has not filtered down to the people living  in the area.  The purpose of the conference was to focus attention on the  technical and social needs of the cocoa zone and to formu­ late comprehensive regional planning fully integrated with  state and federal development schemes. At the conclusion  of the conference a loose organization called the ^Alliance  of Mayors in the Reconcavo" was formed. It will be/respon­ sibility of this group to undertake an inventory of the re­ gion's most pressing needs, draw up specific projects in  such fields as health, education, housing, communications  and power and channel these projects to an appropriate state,  federal or international agency for consideration. The “Alliance of Mayors in the Reconcavo“ was established to address issues in health, education, housing, and more, aiming for integrated regional planning.

The Department of State is proposing an amendment to a 1952 agreement, allowing the Government of Brazil to retain the original negatives from a collaborative aeronautic and topographic mapping program. The U.S. Ambassador is authorized to exchange notes with Brazil to formalize this understanding. The proposal requires Brazil‘s concurrence for the amendment to take effect.

S/AM - SECRETARY SIGNS TREATY WITH SPAIN  (UNCLASSIFIED)  DURING HIS RECENT VISIT TO SPAIN, SECRETARY  KISSINGER SIGNED A NEW FIVE- YEAR TREATY WITH THE GOVERN­ MENT OF SPAIN COVERING MILITARY, ECONOMIC, CULTURAL,  SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL COOPERATION. FORM DS-682  9-61 INCO Fishing The 1968 memorandum discusses the dire state of Brazil‘s fishing industry, particularly in Pará and Amapá. It highlights outdated fishing vessels, limited local ice production, and the predominance of river fishing over sea fishing. Despite the region‘s potential for commercial fishing, inadequate infrastructure leads to high losses, and no significant improvements have been implemented, despite reports to authorities.

His mission was strictly religious —  to establish contaet with the church — and he went as the  personal emissary of Pope Paul. Dom Eugenio confided that  Foreign Minister MagalhSes Pinto asked him to keep his eyes  and ears open during the visit as he was deeply concerned  about Cuban guerrilla activity spreading to the South Amer­ ican continent.  Dom Euge"nio said he returned from Cuba with the profound con­ viction that "it could happen here". He said if the Brazilian  sugar barons and owner-bosses (proprietaries) were able to  witness the results of the Cuban revolution, they would in  self interest force higher wages and better living conditions  on their workers. The situation in Brazil cannot remain as  it is, he added, it is of the utmost urgency that the insen­ sibilities of the ruling class to existing social injustices  be overcome. He said the Brazilian people are very patient  and violence is contrary to their nature, but the pressures  of the world in which they live will make them susceptible  to radical political change. Sales believed that witnessing the Cuban revolution could prompt local elites to improve conditions for workers, highlighting growing social tensions and a rising middle class.

Populorum Progressio Foreign Service of the  United States of America  OUTGOING Amcongen Recife  LIMITED OFFICIAL USE  Charge: Classification Control:  Date: April 12, 1967  ACTION: Amembassy RIO IO36  INFO: Amembassy MONTEVIDEO FOR USDEL 2 Secstate WASHDC 93I  FROM: Amconsul RECIFE 1220  1. Local and regional press and leadership in Northeast Brazil  repeatedly praising Populortim Progressio as re-stateraent imperative  of social justice within terms of Alliance for Progress. References  US reaction to it, however, usually confined to Wall Street Journal  story which called it anti-capitalistic ("warmed-over Marxism").  2. Recognize danger that US endorsement might be taken as medling  in population policies other countries, but this aspect hardly  noted here. Danger in Northeast more likely to be continued protest  by Church leaders based on encyclical, which could eventually make  it property of extremists. May 1 manifesto of Catholic Workers Action  will be next significant event already being telegraphed in press  releases.  3. If not already planned, therefore,Presidential endorsement of  general message of encyclical, if Embassy Rio concurs, would be  desirable corrective in local situation. On April 12, 1967, the U.S. Consulate in Recife reported significant local support in Northeast Brazil for Populortim Progressio, viewed as essential for social justice. However, U.S. media reaction was largely negative. The consulate noted potential backlash from Church leaders, suggesting a Presidential endorsement of the encyclical could improve relations.

Attached is a memorandum of conversation between Dom Eugenio SALES,  the Bishop of Salvador, and officers of the Consulate in Salvador.  COMMENT  2. The memorandum is an interesting sidelight to the controversy  between the Catholic Church and the administration (Ref Airgrams).  Bishop Sales' statement that the situation has been "improved, but not  resolved," is almost certainly correct. It highlights the ongoing controversy between the Catholic Church and the administration, with Bishop Sales noting improvements in relations but emphasizing unresolved issues. He is viewed as a mediator due to his respected, liberal stance within both the Church and government.

FROM : Amconsulate SALVADOR DATE: April 18, 1969  SUBJECT : Church-State Relations As Seen By Cardinal  Archbishop of Salvador, Primate of Brazil.  REF :  ^At 48 years of age, Dom Eugenio Salles is one of the most?  respected and influential prelates of the Catholic Church  in Brazil today and with his elevation to the Cardinalate  may be expected to exert an even greater influence on the  Military Regime. He is fully committed to social progress  but advocates moderation vs. militantism as the most plau­ sible course for the Church at this time.  The attached report of conversation gives Dom EugSnio's  views on the military, political and business sectors of  the society and the role of the Church in promoting so­ cial welfare. Though he is discreet in voicing criti­ cism of the Government (and he qualifies that it is com­ posed of both good and bad elements), he clearly feels  that the punitive phase of IA-5 must soon be replaced by  a positive phase in order to retain the support of the  people. He professes faith that men of good will prevail  and that the challenge for the Church is to identify  these key figures and urge them to move more rapidly to­ wards basic reforms, Dom Eugenio does not have a time­ table against which he measures Government progress and  he remains optimistic about the long-run future of Brazil,  The reporting officer detects a subtle change in Dom  Eugenio1s attitude vis a vis the Military Regime (towards  greater tolerance) possibly because of his new status in  the College of Cardinals, and perhaps as the result of  policy emanating from the Vatican,  FORM nniwmrawTAT. ^Hnff^' For D<">°rWnt Use 0nl* L FBO AID ? *//> I HANDLING INDICATOR NQ 7  TO : Department of State 0£' • ^Efir A  INFO: RIO DE JANEIRO ®^'h:Rfrlf/y\ ? FROM : Amconsulate SALVADOR DATE: Church-State Relations On April 18, 1969, a report discusses Cardinal Eugenio Salles, an influential Catholic leader in Brazil, emphasizing his advocacy for moderation over militancy amid Brazil‘s Military Regime. Dom Eugenio‘s attitude reflects an increasing tolerance towards the regime, possibly influenced by his elevation to cardinal status and Vatican policies.

It highlights the role of religious groups in promoting social change in Brazil, particularly in cooperatives and community development. Sao Paolo State Goevrnment to Raise Circulation Tax Rate / ACTION  CJ>0F>  E REP  /  te  XI INR  S  AID 1 5CA _tei  TAR  NSA  3  CVI  Drafted by: DEPARTMENT OF STATE FM /X xA* m  FOR RM USE ONLY  A-191 UNCLASSIFIED  HANDLING INDICATOR  TO : Department of State  INFO: Amembassy, RIO  FROM Amconsul, SAO PAULO DATE: January 2, 1968  SUBJECT : Sao Paulo State Government to Raise Circulation Tax Rate  REF CERP D  HSao Paulo State Governor Roberto de Abreu SODRE signed a decree ~~'  law on December 29, 1967, under which the rate of the state circulation  tax (ICM) will be raised gradually from the current 15 percent ad-valorem  to 18 percent. The rate will be raised to 16 percent starting  April 1, 1968, to 17 percent effective May 1, 1968, and to a full 18 percent  as of June 1, 1968. Agricultural products will not be subject to any tax  increases.  According to Governor Sodr6, the ICM tax rise will take place not  only in Sao Paulo, but will be adopted uniformly by all the states of  Central-South Brazil. This measure was authorized by Federal Minister  Antonio DELFIM NETO following the November 9, 1967 meeting of the  Secretaries of Finance of all the states of Brazil (see A-148 of  November 9, 1967).  The gradual increase in the state ICM rate to become effective in  April, 1968, rather than in January is aimed at avoiding an additional  inflationary impact on prices to consumers at a time when the increase  as of January 1, 1968, of the federal tax on Industrialized Products-IPM- (a form of excise tax) on several products is liable to influence prices  upward.  The increase in the rate of the ICM to 18 percent will provide significant additional revenue to the state government assuming no adverse impact on business as forecast by the Sao Paulo Federation of Industries. The state retains 80 percent of the tax and the municipality in which the  ECON:A§Ventfea:is 1-2-68  Clearances:  DECLASSIFIED  Authority NMD^(c/jOOO FN 16 1-1-68 BRAZ On January 2, 1968, the Sao Paulo state government announced a gradual increase in the circulation tax (ICM) from 15% to 18%, starting April 1, 1968. Agricultural products will remain exempt. This decision, authorized by Federal Minister Antonio Delfim Neto, aims to avoid inflation amid federal tax increases. The rise is expected to boost state revenue significantly.

Enclosed Book - "The Limits of Growth" MAY 1*02 EDITION  GSA FFMH (« CY1») W1-II.0  ^RNMENT 9 j |\J F'  Memorandum UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT  TO : \USAED Agriculture Staffs DATE: October 26, 1972  1711041 : uf^^^^^A^^u^iire.^Rireau^or Technical Assistance  SUBJECT: Enclosed Book - "The Limits of Growth" — jXJUy^  TA/AGR is enclosing a copy of subject book for the perusal of the  Agricultural Staffs in the USAIDs. Copies already have been forwarded  to the Population Officers.  The book has been the object of praise and blame. It is certainly- controversial, and for that very reason we believe that you will find  it provocative and stimulating. Its message may be stated simply  "Unless current world trends in population growth and industrial  output are checked, and unless pollution is severely curbed, civili­ zation faces a catastrophic collapse within 100 years and perhaps  within 50". In the words of the Science review, the book is a "hard  sell for a computer view of doomsday".  The Chief of TA/AGR's Economic Division has the following comments on  the book:  "This report is a representative example of a beginning  effort leading to better understanding of the complex  interrelationships between five basic factors: population,  agricultural production, natural resources, industrial  production, and pollution. The global modeling effort  provides for ordering a set of assumptions and corrective  hypotheses for complex systems. As the authors frankly  state, the model is as yet imperfect and much further  study is needed and planned.  "Your attention is drawn to this imaginative, and con­ siderably innovative approach to sector analysis, to  conceptual and quantitative issues making such a first  approximation of dynamic modeling possible and to the  initial findings of the range of first approximation  conditions required for achieving a state of global  equilibrium.  "Serious efforts are underway in some missions with the  Technical Assistance Bureau, assisted by the U. S. University  Community to refine, extend, and elaborate on the sector  approach, outlined in preliminary form in the enclosed  text."  Buy U.S. Savings Bonds Regularly on the Payroll Savings Plan  soir-ioe INF4 Inquiries2 On October 26, 1972, the USAID Agriculture Staff received “The Limits of Growth,“ a controversial book discussing potential catastrophic consequences of unchecked population growth and pollution. The memo highlights the book‘s provocative nature and indicates ongoing efforts to refine the sector analysis approach it presents. It emphasizes the need for further research to understand complex interrelationships between population, resources, and industrial production.

A telegram from Rio de Janeiro, dated August 7, 196*, reports on a “Week of Protest“ against high living costs that culminated in a boycott. Initial efforts were deemed unsuccessful, with minimal impact on labor and business. Propaganda targeted favela residents for a mass meeting, though police were prepared to prevent expanding protests. General activity in downtown appeared normal, indicating the boycott‘s ineffectiveness.

Statement in Preparation for 1970 Officer Evaluation Report aaiiissvoaa  Belaa, Para, Brazil  June 26, 1970  UNCLASSIFIED  QF'ICIAL-INFORMAL  Jfr, Clarence A. Bocmstra  Charge d'affaires a.i.  American Snbassy  Bio de Janeiro, Brazil  Dear Mr. Boonstrai  This letter is sent to you in response to your telegram of  June 19 requesting a statement for use in preparation of my 1970  officer evaluation report. What I have tried to do in the following  in con?)lying with yoiar request is to provide you with a thumbnail  sketch of the Belcaa Consular District, a gemral breakdown of the  purpose of the Cons\ilate and the responsibilities of the principal  officer and a not-so-brief discussion of efforts taken by nyself  since my arrival to fulfill my responsibilities.  Belem is a two-man post with foiir Brazilian employees responsible  for a consular district measuring 2,000 miles by 1,200 miles. The  district, idiich comprises about hOj^ of the total land ai^ of Brazil,  is coextensive with the Brazilian North ot Amazon area. The region ia  charactexdzed by a sparse and unevenly distributed population (5 mlliion),  a subsistence agriculture and extractive industrial economy and ijranense  couanunication and transportation problems. Long neglected, it has only  been within the last ten years that the Brazilian government has made  a concentrated effoxd to encoxirage develojanent and to begin the inte­ gration of ti^ region into the national economy.  Even so, in spite of current efforts, the area is still of marginal  importance economical].y and politically when compared with other regions  of Brazil and most likely will remain so for the forseeable future. From  a pyschological standpoint, however, Amazonia is of major importance.  It has markedly influenced the Brazilian psyche and the obsession with  the area should continue until such time as it becomes an integral part  of Brazil and the federal government no longer feels that its sovereignty  over the region is threatened.  Residing within the consular district are an estimated 1,?00  American citizens. Many are missionaides, but an ever-increasing number  of U.S. ccmipanies and businesaaen, attracted lyr investment opportunities,  are establishing local operations and taking up residence. Tourist  traffic from the United States, including many adventuroxis young people  travelling on a shoe 8tx*ing, is also growing.  UNCLASSIFIED PER - Personnel On June 26, 1970, a letter was addressed to Clarence A. Boonstra regarding a 1970 officer evaluation report. It outlines the Belem Consular District‘s responsibilities, which covers a vast, sparsely populated area in Brazil. The region, pivotal to Brazil‘s psyche yet economically marginal, is experiencing increased American presence, including missionaries and business interests, amidst ongoing development efforts.

CONFIDENTIAL  HANDLING INDICATOR  TO = Department of State 1566 AUG 9  INFO J RIO DE JANEIRO, BRASILIA  ANALYSIS BRANCH On,  FROM  SUBJECT  REF Amconsulate, Belo Horizonte DATE: August 3, 1966  XXVIII Congress of National Union of Students  Consulate's A-lj., July 26, 1966  1. Thanks to positive and imaginative planning and the co- ~~'  operation and coordinated efforts of the DVS, Military Police,  Civil Guard and Army units, the movements and activities of  UNE students were effectively controlled and Belo Horizonte  was spared being subjected to student riots and demonstrations  as was originally feared.  2. However, in spite of police efforts to prevent a meeting,  the students managed to convene a clandestine meeting in the  parish hall of the Franciscan Church in Belo Horizonte, with  the foreknowledge and consent of the Franciscan priests. The  meeting was held on the night of July 28 and early morning  hours of July 29* Some 150 to 200 students were present at  the meeting. The only action reportedly taken by them was to  present a single slate of candidates for the UNE directorate  for next year* The entire slate of candidates was elected by  acclamation by the delegates present. Representatives of the  Communist Party of Brazil (PCB) and Popular Action (AP) were  known to have been present at the meeting. PCB representa­ tives reputedly proposed that the UNE be dissolved to avoid  further conflict between the students and Federal Government.  The majority of the students, led by AP representatives, are  said to have rejected the proposal.  3» 0ut-of«*town students were estimated by police authorities  to have numbered never more than 200 to 250 and only a small  fraction of Belo Horizonte students became identified with or  participated in UNE activities. On August 3, 1966, a report from the US consulate in Belo Horizonte highlighted the successful control of UNE student activities during the XXVIII Congress of National Union of Students, preventing riots. Despite police efforts, about 200 students held a clandestine meeting, electing a UNE directorate slate. PCB members suggested dissolving UNE, but most students rejected this.

JOHNSON, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED  STATES, AND ROBERTO SANCHEZ VILELLA, GOVERNOR OF THE COMMONWEALTH  OF PUERTO RICO, ANNOUNCED TODAY THAT A JOINT DOMINICAN-PUERTO  RICAN ECONOMIC COMMISSION WOULD BD APPOINTED AND WOULD MEET  DURING THE FIRST WEEK OF NOVEMBER IN SANTO DOMINGO TO BEGIN  TECHNICAL PLANNING TO DEVELOP CLOSER AND MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL  ECONOMIC RELATIONS BETWEEN THEIR PEOPLES.  2. BEGIN QUOTE THE COMMISSION, WHOSE FUNCTIONS HAVE BEEN UHDE.R  STUDY FOR SEVERAL MONTHS, WILL OPERATE THROUGH THAEAUSPICIES OF  THE TECHNICAL SECRETARIAT OF THE PRESIDENCY OF THE DOMINICAN  REPUBLIC AND THE CORPORACION DE DESARRDLO ECONOMICO DEL CARIBE  IN PUERTO RICO AND WILL BE COMPOSED OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM  THOSE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES DIRECTLY CONCERNED WITH THE DEVEL­ OPMENT AND COORDINATION OF ECONOMIC AFFAIRS.  5. THE PRESEDENT OF THE UNITED STATES, THt.  PRESIDENT OF THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC, AND THE GOVERNOR OF THE  COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO EKPRESStLD THEIR DESIRE THAT THOSE  ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES WOULD COOPERATE AND ASSIST, AS  APPROPRIATE, IN THIS JOINT EFFORT. It will convene in Santo Domingo in early November, focusing on mutual benefits under the auspices of respective governmental agencies. The initiative aims to foster economic development in the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, and the Caribbean, complementing existing international efforts.

Bierrenbach assigned to  Washington.  4. Court disallows Deputies1  "personal allowance".  1. Lacerdistas dismayed.  Carlos LACERDA'S blast at the Brazilian Supreme Court  (Rio Weeka 49) made his SSo Paulo followers squirm, and his  ensuing attacks on President CASTELLO BRANCO*s Ministers  caused one of the loudest local flaps since the Revolution.  Lacerda followers are probably more than ever a minority in  SSo Paulo, but they are a strong and vocal minority tied  closely to the military "hard-line" group. The civilian  pillar of the Lacerdista movement here is the daily 0 Estado  de S. Paulo, owned by the patrician Mesquita family. Never­ theless, the Mesquitas' editorials last week took exception  L_ Decontrolled following December 10, 1984  LIMITED OFFICIAL USE J  DS-323 FORyDEPT. Wight, Jr. DCProper/el 12-7-64  Clearances: GENERAL REPORTS & STATISTICS A December 10, 1964, weekly summary from the U.S. Department of State discusses political tensions in Brazil, particularly regarding Carlos Lacerda‘s criticism of the Supreme Court and the government. Despite Lacerda‘s diminished support in São Paulo, his faction remains influential, especially with military backing. The summary also mentions political reconciliations and staffing changes in Washington.

Department of State  Info s Brasilia^ Hio de Janeiro, Sao P^^foo^^  AmOonaul, Porto Alegre October 171969  Biographic Notes on :Jcneral of the Army Krailio GarSbtasu  Medici, President ^ilect of Brazil /  lo Family Background; Both the Garastazu and t^-ie Medici  families are substantial and respected in the region of Bage on  the Uruguayan border. Neither is an old family in the tradit­ ional sense, however. On both sides^the families were more or  less established by General Garastazu Medici's grandfathers.  His Medici grandfather emigrated from Italy late in the last  century and attempted to enter Brazil but was unable to do so  because he was not able to establish that he and his wife were  legally married. !Ie was ultimately successful in gaining en­ trance to Uruguay and the family finally settled on the Uru­ guayan border with Brazil. The General s Garastazu grandfather  was a more colorful character. A cattle drover and cowboy, he  drifted iiito the region as a young man late in the last cen­ tury, probably from either Argentina or Uruguay. By the time  of his death at the age of eighty two he had spawned a large  family and acquired considerable holdings in land and cattle.  According to family legend he could ait a horse as well as his  sons and grandsons almost to the tin^ of his death, and even  ride them into the ground, Garastazu is a Basque name, and the  General's grandfather combined the characteristics for which the  race is famous - personal toughness, shrewdness, stubbornessii  and taciturnity. Many of these chareoteriatics are shared by  the General.  2. General ;imillo Garastazu Medici was born in Bage on Dec­ ember k.g 1909';-J50 Emillo Medici and Julia Garastazu Medici,  is one of five children. One of his brothers became a noted  doctor in Porto Alegre. Others ore ranchers or professional  men. hike many families in the region both the Medici and He POL 15-1 Heads of State 1969 (Classified) The document provides biographic notes on General Emilio Garastazu Medici, President of Brazil, detailing his family background. Both the Garastazu and Medici families, emerging from humble origins, gained respect in Bage, near the Uruguayan border. His Italian grandfather struggled with legal marriage to enter Brazil but settled in Uruguay, while the Garastazu grandfather was a cattle drover known for personal toughness. General Medici was born on December 4, 1909.

January 18 Statement of FMP (Popular Mobilization Front) L-8& CONFIDENTIAL  Department of State  INFO : POLAD/CINCSO  AMB  mm  ]*OL(5)  POL/R  SVCATT  IHNECCN  ECON  FINATT  LABATT  BraeiliaI I ITB AmEmbassy RIO DE JANEIRO January 22, 1964  January 18 Statement of FMP (Popular Mobilization Front)  Popular Mobilization Front (FMP) leaders met in Leonel  Brizola's Rio apartment on January 18 and issued a statement  which seems to condition FMP support for President Ooulart on,  among other things, "immediate" action in the following fields  which, the document stated, are "ail within the exclusive  competence of the President": a) Institution of exchange and  coffee export monopolies; b) breaking off negotiations on the  AMFORP case, and the expropriation of public service concessions,  «-)including the Hanna concessions; e) expropriation of the  •^Oapuava refinery; f) measures against speculation by "foodstuff  monopolies" and the nationalization of foreign meat packers,  mills, powdered milk plants and pharmaceutical industry;  g) signing of the SUPRA land expropriation decree, which should  not include "small and medium properties"; h) a return to  their original units of sergeants transferred because of  "political persecution"; J) "democratization" of the press,  radio and television.  The statement also a) called for "effective respect for  the policy of self-determination and non-intervention, notably  in relation to Cuba, and support of the struggle of the  Panamanian people in defense of their territorial integrity";  b) reaffirmed the validity of the FMP statements of December  17-16 and "in particular" of Pernambuco Governor Arraes1  statement of December 18 (lunbtel 1270); and c) said that the  FMP will "intensify the mobilisation of the people by all  possible means".  GROUP 3: Downgrade at 12-yr intervals,  not automatically declassified.  CONFIDENTIAL  POL:AArbnales/rstp DCM - Minister Main  DECLASSIFIED  AuthorityjJ lO P S"3 I POL 13 Non-PartyBlocs FMP PopularMobilizationFront 1965 On January 18, 1964, leaders of the Popular Mobilization Front (FMP) met in Rio de Janeiro, issuing a statement outlining conditions for supporting President Goulart. Key demands included monopolies on exchange and coffee, expropriation of concessions, and media democratization. They also called for respect for self-determination policies and pledged to intensify public mobilization.

Attached is completed Government  Progress statement on compliance, Title I,  fourth-quarter CY 1969.  2. EVALUATION OF GOB STATEMENT  a. Usual Marketing Requirements:  (1) Questions on eligibility of reported imports  Brazil's wheat imports during October-December 1969  totaled 726,288 metric tons of which 354,760 tons were  imported under Title I, P.L. 480, leaving 371,528 tons  of imports qualifying for usual marketing requirements.  (2) Actions by government, e.g., release of foreign  exchange, issuance of import licenses, etc  Import licenses for wheat and wheat flour are not granted  to the private trade. The Government of Brazil, through  the Bank of Brazil's Foreign Trade Department (Cacex),  is the sole importer ©f these items and Issues import  licenses to itself for this purpose. Millers purchase  both imported and domestically produced wheat directly  from the government under the GGB's wheat allocation  system.  (3) Estimates on or problems concerning government's  meeting UMR's.  Brazil imported 371,528 tons of wheat in the fourth  quarter of CY 1969 which qualify for CY 1969 usual  marketing requirements. This brings to 1,557,888 tons  the total Imports qualifying for CY 1969 usual marketing  requirements.  (4) Other comments.  Brazil purchased 470,000 tons of wheat cm free world  open tender basis during CY 1969 (435*000 tons from the  CNCLAS AGR FAA (AGR. AttachC's Reports) (Trips and General Rep.) The document is a Quarterly Field Compliance Report detailing Brazil‘s wheat imports for October-December 1969 under Title I, P.L. 480. Brazil imported 726,288 metric tons, with 354,760 tons qualifying under Title I. The government, through the Bank of Brazil, controls wheat imports, issuing licenses solely for itself, with a total of 1,557,888 tons qualifying for usual marketing requirements.

NSC ANALYSIS THOROUGH AND THOUGHTFUL* MOREOVER*  EXAMINATION OF EACH COMPONENT OF US INTERESTS IN BRAZIL VALID  AND REALISTIC IN MOST INSTANCES^ BELIEVE HOWEVER THAT WHETHER  WE DESCRIBE INTERESTS AS TANGIBLE OR INTANGIBLE* OR WHETHER WE  REFER TO SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP OR FIRST AMONG EQUALS* NSC  ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUE INHERENTLY TENDS TO UNDER VALUE THE OVERALL  IMPORTANCE OF BRAZIL TO THE US. A telegram from the U.S. Embassy in Rio de Janeiro discusses a National Security Council (NSC) analysis of U.S. interests in Brazil. The message critiques the analysis for undervaluing Brazil‘s overall importance, likening it to assessing a balanced diet by evaluating individual nutrients without recognizing their collective significance. It also suggests that the analysis neglects Brazil‘s potential role in key foreign policy issues.

Argentine Sensitivities Toward Brazil Sharply Increase 12/24/1971 DEPARTMENT OF STATE  Washington. D.C. 20S2O  5 S/S 7120572  RS/R FILES  Attention **  CONFIDENTIAL  0 r MEMORANDUM FOR MR. HENRY A. KISSINGER  COPIEF TO: THE WHITE HOUSE  J  'c,-/pc Subject: Argentine Sensitivities Toward Brazil  n_ Sharply Increase  Argentina is extremely concerned that the United  States may have selected Brazil as its chosen instrument  in dealing with Latin America and that the United States  may be encouraging or permitting Brazil to establish a  form of hegemony over the rest of Latin America. The  long-standing Argentine animosity toward and envy of  Brazil have been sharply exacerbated by the visit of  President Medici of Brazil to Washington and the resultant  press reports suggesting that the U.S. has singled out "5  Brazil as the most important nation in Latin America. A ^  rash of editorials has broken out in the Argentine press  decrying what they assume to be official U.S. Government y  policy to place Brazil at the head of Latin America. The ^  Medici visit has also triggered off a flurry of rumors s\  and speculation about a possible U.S. invitation to  Argentine President Lanusse to visit Washington.  Argentine officials have queried Embassy officers  about press statements emanating from Washington during  the visit of the Brazilian president which suggested that  the U.S. Government considers Brazil to be the most  important country in Latin America. In pursuance of their  apprehensions about Argentina's being discarded, senior  Foreign Ministry officials in Buenos Aires have told  United States officials that they believe Argentina has  an important although modest role to play in the Southern  Cone, exercising a moderating influence over countries  such as Peru, Bolivia, Paraguay, Uruguay, and, to some  extent, Chile.  CONFIDENTIAL MICROFILMED  *«A-U/AT0 -.vif -S.TOIVW.1 BY S/S-I POLITICAL AFFAIRS & RELATIONS The memorandum from the U.S. Department of State expresses Argentina‘s growing concern over the U.S. favoring Brazil in Latin American affairs, particularly after Brazilian President Medici‘s Washington visit. Argentine officials fear being sidelined and have voiced their belief in Argentina‘s significant role in the region. The situation has led to increased tension and negative press in Argentina regarding U.S. policy.

Revised Bank of Brazil accounts indicate that the net foreign asset  position of the Brazilian monetary authorities improved by only $3«9  million during the first semester of 19^7, not $24.1 million as pre­ viously reported. Following relative stability during the first semester  the net foreign asset position deteriorated sharply during July and August  by slightly more than $100 mi Hi or. and weekly estimates show a further  decline of almost $90 million tnrough October 20 as shown in Table I.  2. The deterioration in net foreign assets during July was anticipated  owing to the low level of coffee receipts and the heavy repayments of  suppliers credits and project loans during that month, but August should  have shewn some improvement. The major cause of the deteriorating  foreign exchange position which continued into October has been heavy  speculation against the cruzeiro. This speculation started early in  August and intensified following the implementation of Central Bank  Resolution 62 control on the manual market which was interpreted as a  sign of a low level of exchange reserves (See A-204, August 31* 1967).  3. The exchange speculation took two major forms: early closing of  exchange contracts for imports and financial remittances through In­ struction 289. As importers closed exchange contracts for imports,  the commercial banks obtained the necessary exchange cover from the  Bank of Brazil (agent for the Central Bank). Exchange cover provided  to the "private banks rose from an average of $7 million per month  earlier in 1967 to $44 million in July, $80 million in August and $124  million in September. Governor Paulo Pimentel's Influence Over Parana Politics dW»6JN/ACTION  RM/ R REP AF  ARA EUR FE  N E A CU INR  E P IO  L FBO AID  I  AGR COM FRB  INT LAB TAR  T R XMB AIR  ARMY  f CIA  JLO NAVY  OSD USI A  /o NSA  3  ra  i  o  o  afted by:  POL:JDB DEPARTMENT OF STATE Toe /S &£A^-L  FOR RM USE ONLY  A-429 LIMITED OFFICIAL USE  TO NO- HANDLING INDICATOR  • Department of State &TATF ^  INFO: BRASILIA, RIO DE JANEIRO J R/Cty ^  FROM Amconsul SAO PAULO DATE: October 25, 1968  SUBJECT : Governor Paulo Pimentel's Influence Over Parana Politics  REF  r  SUMMARY 1  Parana's Governor Paulo PIMENTEL retains a firm control over ARENA  party machinery and politicians in the state. This control is exercised  with the assistance of ARENA'S General Secretary Anibal Khoury and the  use of a system of rewards and punishment to keep politicians in line.  The Governor's popular support does not appear to be as great as that  enjoyed by Senator and ex-Governor Ney Braga who reportedly wants to  be a candidate for governor in 1970. The rift between Pimentel and Braga  continues to exist and some observers are speculating that Pimentel will  try to keep Braga from getting his name on the ballot.  Introduction  In a separate report (see Sao Paulo's A-426) concerning the November 15,  1968, elections in Parana, the firm control of Governor Paulo Pimentel  and ARENA State Secretary Anibal Khoury over the state's ARENA party  organization was mentioned. The present report deals in greater detail  with the Governor's control over the party organization and with extent  of popular support for the Governor's Administration. It also discusses  some of the prospective candidates for governor of Parana in 1970 and  Pimentel's ambitions.  L_ EXEMPT FROM AUTOMATIC DECONTROL  LIMITED OFFICIAL USE J  FOR DEPT. On January 14, 1957, President Castello Branco announced a decision regarding the control of aviation in Brazil. The Navy will manage helicopters for various missions, while the Air Force will control fixed-wing aircraft. A joint training center is to be established. The decision, justified by financial and military considerations, received a generally favorable press reaction, with minimal public dissent from the Air Force or Navy.

Council of United States Universities for Brazilian Rural Development \)A4'  COUNCIL OF UNITED STATES UNIVERSITIES  for  Cop BRAZILIAN RURAL DEVELOPMENT  We are pleased to announce the creation of the COUNCIL OF  UNITED STATES UNIVERSITIES FOR BRAZILIAN RURAL DEVELOPMENT.  The University of Arizona, Mississippi State University, The  Ohio State University, Purdue University and The University of Wisconsin  constitute the founding membership of the COUNCIL. These universities have  major agricultural education and research development programs in Brazil.  For several years, they have been working closely with sister institutions  in Brazil in an attempt to increase the rate at which the latter become  able to better serve the needs of the Brazilian society. Substantive  progress toward this end has been made; much remains to be done before the  Brazilian system of higher education and research in agriculture will be  in position to contribute that which it must to the economic and social  development of that great nation. COUNCIL members are fully committed to  contributing in such ways as they might to this mission.  In a larger sense, there exists an urgent need to create an  international resource in the form of United States education and scientific  competence in matters relevant to Brazilian agriculture. Effectiveness of  action programs in Brazilian rural development has been, is and will continue  to be hampered by a paucity of knowledge about relevant social, economic and  technical forces. Present and near future capacity of the agricultural edu­ cation and research system in Brazil is inadequate to provide the knowledge  requirements necessary to rapid agricultural development, economic growth and  social progress. The systematic development of scholarly centers of excel­ lence treating of these matters within United States universities has the  potential of paying extremely high dividends both in terms of attainment  of Brazilian national goals and in the establishment of long-run, mutually  desirable and acceptable relationships between the United States and Brazil.  In still broader context, United States colleges of agriculture  are faced with the necessity of developing a comprehensive international  dimension to their traditional education and research missions. This neces­ sity grows out of secular growtli in the interdependence, of United States  agriculture and that of the rest of the world and inescapable responsibili­ ties to expand the scientific knowledge base to non-domestic physical, bio­ logical and human behavioral phenomena. It is given additional impetus by  the educational demands of young people and adults desiring careers in  international agriculture or in a domestic agriculture increasingly sensitive  to events abroad.  COUNCIL members desire to strengthen their scientific and educa­ tional capabilities requisite to the completion of developmental tasks abroad. Agricultural University Council The Council of United States Universities for Brazilian Rural Development has been established, comprising the University of Arizona, Mississippi State University, Ohio State University, Purdue University, and the University of Wisconsin. This initiative aims to enhance agricultural education and research in Brazil, addressing barriers to rural development while fostering international collaborations and expanding the role of U.S. agriculture in global contexts.

FROM : Amconsul RECIFE ' BRANCH  DATE: Sept. 9, 1970  SUBJECT : Northeast Brazil Legislative Elections Preview  REF  r Brasilia A-50  SUMMARY  In the November legislative elections to be held in the seven-state  Northeastern area extending from Alagoas to Maranhao, the government  ARENA is expected to win between 70 and 75 percent of the senate,  federal deputy and state deputy seats at stake. It appears unlikely  that the MDB will elect a majority either of any state's federal  deputy delegation or in a state legislature. To date, the political  campaign is being carried out on the personalistic and parochial  basis typical of Northeastern Brazilian politics. National issues  are being largely ignored and neither the campaign nor the election  results are expected to produce a test of popular opinion or an  indication of popular will. To the extent that national issues are  being raised, ARENA orators are praising the personality of President  Me*dici and economic gains of the Revolution, while those of the MDB  are urging a return to democracy and full human and civil rights. The  normal Northeast voting patterns are expected to hold, with the  opposition MDB running well in urban centers and ARENA sweeping the  more populous rural areas. The greatest threat to ARENA appears to be  widespread voter indifference in its rural strongholds. As usual,  the Brazilian proportional voting system will considerably blur the  significance of the election results. Even the state-wide senate  results are expected to be ambiguous due to the virtual certainty that  the MDB vote in these races will be swelled by normally ARENA voters  casting their second vote for the MDB due to persisting intra-ARENA  hostilities. Because this type of cross-balloting is permitted in  the senate races, ARENA leaders are attempting to counteract second- vote defections by demanding "partisan fidelity." Schwab of  Washington, D.C. regarding future goals and objectives of research  in agricultural economic development in Brazil. He suggested that  I contact you directly.  Enclosed is an abstract of my Ph.D. dissertation which gives  you some idea of my background in Brazil. I have asked Mr. Arthur  R. Significant alterations were made in the original  version of the bill as reported in the referenced airgram. The most impor­ tant of these permanently equips the National Monetary Council with a new  fiscal stabilizer. A translation of the bill as passed by the Senate is  attached as an enclosure to this airgram.  In terms of its original import the bill still provides fiscal incen­ tives for stabilization and productivity increase, namely: 1) a reduction  from 28 to 20 percent of the tax rate on 1965 business incomes for firms  both containing their sales price increases over the 10 months ending  December 31, 1965 to within 15 percent over levels verified at the outset  of the period and increasing the quantity of 1965 sales by at least 5  percent over 196k levels and 2) an increase of from 28 to 35 percent of  the tax rate on 1965 business incomes for firms increasing sales prices  by more than 30 percent over the above mentioned period. Note that one  important change from the original version is a redefinition of productivity  iy performance; the original version called upon firms to increase total  nominal receipts by 50 percent over 196k levels rather than quantity sold.  With regard to the fiscal penalty the original version was changed to  exempt firms which do not increase gross profit margins over 196k levels  or which can attribute price increases in excess of 30 percent to exchange  rate movements or increases in primary materials prices charged by "mixed  entity" suppliers. /  The most important new provision of the bill is that authorizing  the National Monetary Council to reduce or eliminate the federal excise  UNCLASSIFIED FOR DEPT. A-190, December 19, 1966. DATE: January 16, 1967  The November 15, 1966 direct congressional elections resulted in a  significant turnover in the 59 member Paulista representation in the  Federal Chamber of Deputies. Among SSo Paulo's deputies there will  be 25 newcomers, a change of over 40% in the state's delegation. As  ' the Consulate General has reported (A-190), Arena lost two seats in  November and will send 32 deputies to the new session of the Chamber.  Five Arena incumbents did not run for reelection and eight Arena deputies  who sought another term were defeated. Thus Arena will present eleven  new Paulistas in the Chamber. Among MDB's contingent of 27 deputies,  over half - 14 - are newly elected to Congress. Two opposition deputies  retired and ten were rejected by voters on election day.  Attached are brief political biographies of SSo Paulo's 25 new Chamber  representatives—some of whom are well-known, established S2o Paulo  political figures and others of whom are still relatively unknown, at  least in the state capital. For each new deputy the Consulate General  has attempted to supply information on political attitudes and for most  of them some sort of projection has been hazarded on their possible  posture in the next Congress. However, as many Brazilian politicians  in the past have shown extreme flexibility, it is conceivable that formerly- held sentiments and old allegiances may not necessarily be infallible in­ dications as to future behavior. It is entirely possible, then, that in  some cases the rough political evaluations offered below may be far off  the mark as predictions of the conduct of new Paulista deputies in Congress,  l_ J  23 CONFIDENTIAL  LW.eIf ."Wig^Tr".Appr FOR DKPT. It outlines the shift in representation, noting that Arena lost seats, while MDB gained new members. Attached biographies detail the political attitudes of the new deputies, highlighting their potential future behavior.
